<<<<<<< HEAD
A discourse of divine providence I. In general: that there is a providence exercised by God in the world. II. In particular: how all Gods providences in the world, are in order to the good of his people. By the late learned divine Stephen Charnock, B.D. sometime fellow of New-Colledg in Oxon. Treatise of divine providence Charnock, Stephen, 1628-1680. Adams, Richard, 1626?-1698. Veel, Edward, 1632?-1708.
[16], 397, [3] p.
printed by R. Roberts for Thomas Cockerill, at the Three Legs in the Poultrey, near the Stocks-Market, London : 1684.
Originally published in 1680 as: A treatise of divine providence (Wing C3712). "To the reader" signed: Richard Adams. Edward Veal. Reproduction of original in the Folger Shakespeare Library, Washington, D.C.
=======

In particular: how all Gods providences in the world, are in order to the good of his people. By the late learned divine Stephen Charnock, B.D. sometime fellow of New-Colledg in Oxon. Treatise of divine providence Charnock, Stephen, 1628-1680. Adams, Richard, 1626?-1698. Veel, Edward, 1632?-1708.
[16], 397, [3] p.
printed by R. Roberts for Thomas Cockerill, at the Three Legs in the Poultrey, near the Stocks-Market, London : 1684.
Originally published in 1680 as: A treatise of divine providence (Wing C3712). "To the reader" signed: Richard Adams. Edward Veal. Reproduction of original in the Folger Shakespeare Library, Washington, D.C.
